samprapti.sancharaSthana: Urdhwa Marga (Upper channels of the body)

bheda: A specific type of Raktapitta, which is easier to treat than the downward type.

chikitsa.shamana:
Tarpana (nourishment) and Stambhana (hemostasis) are key.
Ahara: Sheeta, Tikta, Kashaya rasa. Use Laja, Mudga, Amlaki, Draksha. Goat's milk is beneficial.
Vihara: Complete rest.
chikitsa.shodhana: The line of treatment is Virechana (purgation). This is a unique principle where a downward therapy (Virechana) is used to treat an upward moving disease.

rupa: Shweta-Tamra Varna, Tanu Mandala (White or coppery, thin patches)
Gharshane Rajah Patati (Sheds powdery scales on rubbing)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Bahya Twak (Outer layer of skin), especially chest

bheda: A type of Kshudra Kushtha (minor skin disease).

chikitsa.shamana: Local treatment is highly effective. Lepa (paste application) with Tikta-Kashaya (bitter-astringent) herbs is the main treatment. Avoid oily applications.
chikitsa.shodhana: Siravyadha (venesection) is the advised Shodhana. Virechana can also be done to pacify the doshas.

correlation: Chronic Fever / Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO)
nidana: Apathya Sevana during Jwara (Improper diet during acute fever)
Dosha Seshata (Residual morbidity after fever subsides)
Alpa Bala Purusha (Person with low immunity)
purvarupa: The episode of preceding acute fever
rupa: Manda Vega Jwara (Low-grade fever, often in the afternoon)
Persists for a long duration (21 days or more)
upashaya: Ghrita and Ksheera Prayoga (Use of medicated ghee and milk)

samprapti.dushya: Rasa, Rakta, and deeper Dhatus, Oja
samprapti.srotas: All Srotas, especially deeper Dhatu-vaha srotas
samprapti.agni: Dhatwagni Mandya (Impairment of tissue metabolism) is the key pathology

bheda: A specific stage or type of Jwara, characterized by chronicity.

chikitsa.shamana:
Treatment focuses on Rasayana (rejuvenation) and Brimhana (nourishment).
Ahara: Light but nourishing. Medicated milk (Ksheerapaka) and ghee are mainstays. Use Guduchi, Ashwagandha, Draksha.
chikitsa.shodhana: Requires very gentle Shodhana. Snehana with Tikta Ghrita (bitter medicated ghee) followed by Mridu Virechana. Yapana Basti (nourishing/rejuvenating enemas) are highly recommended.

rupa: Ruk, Toda, Stambha (Pain, pricking sensation, stiffness) starting from Griva (neck) and radiating down the Bahu (arm), Prakoshtha (forearm) to Hastanguli (fingers)
Bahu Karma Kshaya (Loss of function/weakness of the arm)
bheda: A type of Vatavyadhi, considered the upper limb counterpart of Gridhrasi (Sciatica).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara & Vihara: Vata-pacifying diet. Avoid cold and dry foods. Rest in acute stage.
Local: Lepa application over the neck and arm.
chikitsa.shodhana: Nasya is the most effective treatment. Local Snehana and Nadi Sweda are highly effective. Basti and Virechana pacify systemic Vata. Agnikarma at specific points is also performed.

rupa: Granthila, Uchrita, Vakra Sira Jala (Tortuous, dilated, knotted network of veins, usually in the legs)

samprapti.dosha: Vata (causes dilation and pain), Pitta-Rakta (cause discoloration and burning)
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to the path of the veins

bheda: A type of Granthi roga affecting the Sira (veins).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Rakta prasadaka (blood purifying) and Vata pacifying diet.
Vihara: Avoid prolonged standing. Use compression stockings (Bandhana).
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (Bloodletting) is the primary treatment. Jalauka (leech therapy) is highly effective. Siravyadha (venesection) is also performed. In advanced cases, Shastra Karma (surgery) is advised.

nidana: Ishta Labha / Ishta Viyoga Chinta (Worry about attaining/losing desired things)

chikitsa.shamana:
Sattvavajaya (psychotherapy) is very important. Reassurance, counseling, meditation, Pranayama.
Ahara: Vata-Pitta pacifying, Medhya diet. Use milk, ghee, almonds.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana with Medhya Ghritas. Shirodhara is the most effective treatment for calming the mind. Nasya and Mridu Virechana are also beneficial.

bheda: A type of Nasa Roga (nasal disease). Can be Vataja, Pittaja, etc. based on symptoms.

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Pratisarana (rubbing) with Kshara (caustic alkali) or other Lekhana (scraping) powders. Nasya with Lekhana oils.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is primarily a surgical condition. Shastra Karma (Excision with a specific instrument called Nasa-arsha-shastra) followed by Agnikarma (cautery) is the definitive treatment.

rupa: Aswedanam, Mahavastu, Matsya-shakala-upamam (Absence of sweating in the lesion, covers a large area, resembles fish scales)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Kushtha (minor skin disease).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Tikta rasa pradhana diet. Avoid incompatible foods, dairy, and heavy foods.
Local: Frequent application of medicated oils.
chikitsa.shodhana: Repeated Shodhana is the key. Snehapana (internal oleation) with Mahatiktaka or Panchatikta Ghrita followed by Vamana and Virechana are the main treatments.

rupa: Chirat Prasiktam / Rakta yuktam Shukram (Delayed ejaculation / Hematospermia)
bheda: A primary Dhatu Kshaya condition, a cause of Klaibya (impotence) and Vandhyatva (infertility).

chikitsa.shamana:
This is treated with Vajikarana (Aphrodisiac) and Brimhana (Nourishing) therapies.
Ahara: Use milk, ghee, Masha, nuts, eggs, meat soup. Herbs like Ashwagandha, Kapikacchu, Musli, Shatavari.
chikitsa.shodhana: Mrudu Virechana followed by Brimhana Basti (nourishing enemas with milk, ghee, and aphrodisiac herbs) is the main line of treatment.

rupa: Anartuja, Niruja, Snigdha, Krishna-aruna Varna Granthi (A non-inflammatory, painless, smooth, blackish-red nodule on the skin, present from birth)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga (minor disease). Different from Mashaka (another type of mole).

chikitsa.shamana: No effective medical management for removal.
chikitsa.shodhana: Treatment is surgical. Shastra Karma (Excision) followed by Agnikarma (cautery) to prevent recurrence is the advised line of treatment.

purvarupa: Mild sensation of fullness in the ear
rupa: Teevra Kandu in Karna (Intense itching inside the ear)
Sometimes associated with mild pain and discharge

samprapti.srotodushti: Sanga (due to wax), Kleda (due to moisture)
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to the external ear canal

chikitsa.shamana: Local treatment is primary. First, Karna Shodhana (cleaning of ear wax). Then, Karna Dhavana (washing with decoctions). This is followed by Karna Dhupana (fumigation) and Karna Purana (instilling medicated drops).
chikitsa.shodhana: Vamana and Dhumapana are useful to clear Kapha from the head region.

correlation: Duodenal Ulcer Pain / Peptic Ulcer Pain
nidana: Ati Amla-Katu-Vidahi Bhojana (Excess sour, pungent, burning food)
rupa: Bhojane Jeeryati Shulam (Severe pain that occurs *during* the digestion of food, i.e., a few hours after a meal)
Pain is relieved by Jeerna-ante (after food is fully digested) or by Punar-bhojana (eating again) or by Vamana (vomiting)

samprapti.dosha: Vata (obstructed by Kapha, stimulated by Pitta)
samprapti.agni: Variable, often vitiated by Pitta and Kapha

bheda: A specific type of Shula (colic), sometimes classified under Grahani.

chikitsa.shamana: Ahara: Frequent, small meals. Ksheera (milk) and Ghrita are very beneficial. Avoid spicy, sour, and fried foods. Use Yava (barley), Godhuma (wheat).
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehapana followed by Mridu Virechana is the best treatment to pacify Pitta. Asthapana Basti is used to pacify Vata. Vamana is indicated if Kapha is dominant.

nidana: Vega Dharana (Suppression of urges like sneeze, yawn)
rupa: Hrit-Kantha Avarodha (Feeling of obstruction in chest and throat)

samprapti.dosha: Vata (specifically Udana and Prana Vayu with Pratiloma Gati - upward movement)
samprapti.srotodushti: Vimarga Gamanam (Movement in the wrong path)

bheda: A specific Vatavyadhi, often a symptom of Udavarta.

chikitsa.shamana:
Treatment is Vatanulomana (restoring downward flow of Vata).
Ahara: Warm, oily, carminative diet. Use Hingu, Trikatu, Yavani, warm water. Small, frequent meals.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehapana (internal oleation) followed by Mridu Virechana (mild purgation). Asthapana Basti is highly effective for correcting the path of Vata.

rupa: Ghana, Daha-Raga-Ruja yukta Pidaka on Mukha (Thick, deep-seated papules on the face with burning, redness, and pain)
Nasa Agra Raga (Redness of the tip of the nose)
bheda: Similar to Yauvanapidaka but considered more of a Pitta-Rakta disorder.

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Pitta-pacifying diet. Avoid spicy, sour, fermented foods, and alcohol.
Local: Lepa with cooling herbs like Chandana, Ushira, Sariva.
chikitsa.shodhana: Siravyadha (venesection) and Jalauka (leech therapy) on the face are the most effective treatments. Repeated Virechana is also essential.

correlation: Multiple Sclerosis / Bone Marrow Disorders with Neurological Symptoms
rupa: Asthi Bheda-vat Shula (Deep, splitting pain inside bones)
bheda: A specific type of Gambhira Vatavyadhi (deep-seated Vata disorder).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Brimhana (nourishing) and Vata-pacifying diet. Use milk, ghee, meat soup, and Medhya dravyas.
Vihara: Avoid physical and mental strain.
chikitsa.shodhana: Basti is the primary treatment. Anuvasana and Niruha Basti are administered for a long duration. Shirobasti and Shirodhara are also highly effective. Snehana and Mridu Swedana are important supportive therapies.

correlation: Scalp Disorders (e.g., Seborrheic Dermatitis, Scalp Psoriasis)
rupa: Varies with 9 types. Main symptoms are Darunaka (dandruff), Kandu (itching), Kesha Chyuti (hair fall), Pidaka (eruptions), Daha (burning), and Srava (discharge from scalp)
upashaya: Shiro Abhyanga (Head massage with medicated oil)
Shiro Lepa (Application of paste on scalp)
bheda: 9 types are described, including Darunaka (dandruff), Indralupta (alopecia areata), Khalitya (hair fall), etc.

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Diet according to dosha dominance.
Local: Shiro Abhyanga (head massage) and Shiro Lepa (scalp pack) are mainstays.
chikitsa.shodhana: Siravyadha (venesection from the head) is the primary Shodhana. Virechana and Nasya are also very important for clearing the doshas from the head region.

purvarupa: Vague discomfort in the vaginal tract
rupa: Antar-yonau Ashthila-vat, Vakra, Unnata Granthi (A hard, stone-like, crooked, elevated mass inside the vagina)
bheda: A specific type of Yonivyapad (gynecological disorder).

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Application of Vata-pacifying oils. Yoni Pichu (medicated tampon).
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana and Swedana of the pelvic region. Virechana and Basti are the main lines of treatment to pacify Vata. If it is a large mass, surgical removal may be indicated.

rupa: Mutrena Saha Sharkara Nirgamanam (Passage of gravel or sharp crystals with urine)
bheda: A type of Pittaja Prameha. It is the precursor stage to Pittaja Ashmari (oxalate/urate stones).

chikitsa.shamana: Ahara: Mutrala (diuretic) and Pitta-pacifying diet. Drink plenty of barley water, coconut water, sugarcane juice. Use Gokshura, Varuna, Pashanabheda.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana followed by Mridu Virechana with cooling herbs is the main treatment. Basti is also administered.

nidana: As a complication of other severe diseases
purvarupa: The symptoms of Apatanaka (general tetanic spasms)
rupa: Dehasya Bahirmukha Ayama (Body bends backwards forcefully like a bow - Opisthotonos)
Ura-Griva-Prishta Stambha (Extreme rigidity of chest, neck, and back)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Sarva Sharira, affecting extensors and flexors

bheda: A severe type of Apatanaka (Tetanic convulsions). If the body bends forward, it's called Abhyantarayama.

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment is palliative as the condition is considered Asadhya (incurable). Patient is kept in a dark, quiet room. Abhyanga and Nadi Sweda are performed to relieve spasms.
chikitsa.shodhana: Basti is the only feasible Shodhana, administered with great care to pacify Vata.

nidana: Ati Kshobha (Straining, e.g., in chronic cough or constipation)
purvarupa: Vankshana Shotha (Mild swelling in the groin)
rupa: Antra Nirgamanam (Protrusion of intestine) into Phalakosha (scrotum)
Shotha (Swelling) that increases on standing/straining and reduces on lying down
Adhmana-vat Sparsha (Feels like an air-filled sac)
bheda: The most important type of Vriddhi Roga (scrotal enlargements).

chikitsa.shamana: Medical management is ineffective and contraindicated. Palliative care involves avoiding strain and using abdominal binders.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is strictly a surgical condition. Shastra Karma (Surgery) is the only definitive treatment. Agnikarma (cauterization of the inguinal ring) after surgery was also advised to prevent recurrence.

keyFormulations: Vruddhivadhika Vati (for symptomatic relief pre/post op)

purvarupa: Daha (Burning sensation) along a nerve path
rupa: Daha-Jwara-yukta, Krishna-Rakta-varna Sphota (Blisters with burning and fever, having a blackish-red color)
Eruptions appear in a line or belt-like pattern, usually in Kaksha (axilla), Parshva (flanks), or Uras (chest)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Twak (Skin), along a specific nerve pathway

bheda: A type of Visarpa (spreading skin disease) or a separate Kshudra Roga, specifically Agni-Visarpa like.

chikitsa.shamana:
Treated on the lines of Pittaja Visarpa.
Ahara: Laghu, Sheeta, Tikta diet. Avoid all Pitta-aggravating foods.
Local: Frequent Lepa with cooling herbs (Chandana, Ushira).
chikitsa.shodhana: Mridu Virechana (mild purgation) is the primary line of treatment. Jalauka (leech therapy) over the affected area is very effective for relieving pain and burning.

rupa: Tila-vat, Niruja, Snigdha, Krishna Varna, Sthira Mandala (A painless, smooth, black-colored, stable, mole-like spot on the skin, resembling a sesame seed)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga (minor disease).

chikitsa.shamana: No effective medical management for removal.
chikitsa.shodhana: Treatment is surgical. Kshara Karma (alkaline cautery) or Agnikarma (thermal cautery) can be used to remove it. For larger moles, Shastra Karma (excision) is performed.

rupa: Dante Krishna Chidra (Black cavity in the tooth)
Mala Sanchaya (Food lodgement in the cavity)
upashaya: Holding warm oil in the mouth

samprapti.dosha: Tridoshaja (Vata causes pain, Kapha provides base, Pitta causes inflammation)

bheda: A specific type of Danta Roga (dental disease).

chikitsa.shamana:
Local: Gandusha/Kavala (oil pulling/gargling) with antimicrobial oils. Filling the cavity (Purana) with substances like melted wax and Laksha.
Procedure: Dhumapana (medicated smoking) to relieve pain.
chikitsa.shodhana: The primary treatment is Shodhana of the tooth itself. This includes Nirharana (extraction of the Krimi/necrotic part). If medical management fails, Dantoddharana (tooth extraction) is the final measure.

keyFormulations: Lavanga Taila (Clove oil for pain relief)

rupa: Ubhaya Sakthi Akarmanyata / Shosha (Loss of function and atrophy of both legs)
The patient is unable to walk and has to drag their body

samprapti.dushya: Sira, Snayu, Mamsa, Majja of the lower limbs

bheda: A severe Vatavyadhi, the bilateral counterpart of Khanja (monoplegia of leg).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Brimhana (nourishing) and Vatahara diet. Masha (black gram) is very useful.
Vihara: Focus on rehabilitation and physiotherapy.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana (both internal and external) and Swedana (Pinda sweda, Nadi sweda) are performed for a long duration. Basti is the main line of treatment. Local procedures like Kati Basti are also performed.

purvarupa: Slight redness and irritation in the corner of the eye
rupa: Shukla Mandalat Krishna Mandalam Pravardhate Mamsam (A fleshy growth that starts from the sclera and gradually encroaches upon the cornea)
Vision is obstructed as it covers the pupil

samprapti.udbhavaSthana: Kaninika Sandhi (Inner canthus of the eye)

bheda: 5 types are described based on extent and color.

chikitsa.shamana: Medical management (Lekhana anjana - scraping collyrium) is used in very early stages but is often insufficient.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is a surgical condition. Shastra Karma (Excision using a specific hook-and-knife method) is the definitive treatment. Lekhana (scraping) after excision is also performed to prevent recurrence.

keyFormulations: Surgical procedure is the main treatment

rupa: Raga, Kandu, Pidaka, Daha yukta Twak (Skin is red, itchy, has eruptions, and a burning sensation)
Charmadaranam (Skin becomes painful and peels off easily)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Kushtha (minor skin disease).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Tikta rasa pradhana diet. Avoid sour, salty, and heavy foods.
Local: Frequent application of healing and cooling oils/ghee.
chikitsa.shodhana: Virechana is the best treatment to pacify Pitta and Kapha. Raktamokshana (leech therapy) is very effective for reducing inflammation and itching.

nidana: Severe vitiation of Rajas and Tamas
rupa: Buddhi-Smriti-Mana Vibhrama (Derangement of intellect, memory, and mind)
Patient is in a state of stupor but can be aroused

samprapti.dosha: Pitta, Vata. Manasika Doshas: Rajas, Tamas (Primary).

bheda: A stage of consciousness loss, less severe than Murchha (fainting) and Sanyasa (coma). 4 types: Vataja, Pittaja, Kaphaja, Sannipataja.

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment is to induce Vamana (vomiting) to expel the toxin/doshas. This is followed by Langhana (fasting) and promoting Nidra (sleep). After the acute stage, Deepana-Pachana and Medhya herbs are given.
chikitsa.shodhana: Vamana is the primary and immediate Shodhana procedure.

purvarupa: A non-healing opening on the skin
rupa: Alpa Mukha, Bahu Srava, Antah Gambhira Marga (A small opening on the skin with continuous scanty discharge, leading to a deep, long internal tract)
anupashaya: Closing the external opening without healing the tract

samprapti.dosha: Tridoshaja (Vata creates the tract, Pitta causes suppuration, Kapha causes discharge)
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Creates a 'Nadi' (tract) towards the skin surface

bheda: Vataja, Pittaja, Kaphaja, Sannipataja, Shalyaja (due to foreign body).

chikitsa.shamana: Limited role. Used for wound healing after the primary procedure.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is a prime surgical condition. Kshara Sutra (medicated alkaline thread) therapy is the most famous and effective treatment, which simultaneously cuts, scrapes, and heals the tract. Alternatively, Shastra Karma (excision of the entire tract) is performed.

sadhyaAsadhyata: Sadhya (for mother's life, fetus may be lost)
purvarupa: Kati-Vankshana Shula (Pain in low back and groin)
rupa: Yoni dwara Rakta Srava (Bleeding per vaginum)
Expulsion of the product of conception
bheda: Garbha Srava (Bleeding up to 4th month, when fetus is in liquid state)
Garbha Pata (Expulsion from 5th-6th month, when fetal parts are formed).

chikitsa.shamana:
For threatened abortion (Garbha Kshobha): Complete bed rest. Stambhana (hemostatic) and Garbha Sthapaka (progestogenic) herbs. Sheeta (cooling) therapies.
After miscarriage: Ashwasana (reassurance) followed by Garbhashaya Shodhana (uterine cleansing) treatment.
chikitsa.shodhana: Contraindicated.

rupa: Vartma Antah Rakta-Sarshapa-Sannibha Pidaka (Red, mustard seed-like eruptions/granules on the inner surface of the eyelids)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to the conjunctiva of the eyelids

bheda: A specific type of Vartma Roga (disease of eyelids).

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Pratisarana (rubbing) with Lekhana (scraping) powders. Application of Lekhana Anjana (scraping collyrium).
chikitsa.shodhana: This is a para-surgical condition. Lekhana Karma (therapeutic scraping of the conjunctival nodules with a specific instrument or rough leaves) is the primary treatment. Siravyadha (venesection) from the forehead is also performed.

purvarupa: Slight dryness or discoloration of lips
rupa: Varies with type. Symptoms include Sphutanam (cracking), Raga (redness), Shotha (swelling), Daha (burning), Kandu (itching), and Pidaka (eruptions) on the lips.

samprapti.dushya: Twak, Rakta, Mamsa of the lips

bheda: 8 types are described based on dosha: Vataja, Pittaja, Kaphaja, Sannipataja, Raktaja, Mamsaja, Medoja, and Abhighataja.

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Lepa (paste application) and Abhyanga (oleation) with medicated ghee or oil is the primary treatment.
chikitsa.shodhana: Siravyadha (venesection, specifically below the tongue) is the most effective Shodhana procedure. Nasya and Virechana are also used according to the Dosha.

nidana: Leaving the child in an empty or inauspicious place
Considered to be caused by imperceptible entities (Grahas)
purvarupa: Child becomes irritable, cries without reason
rupa: Varies with the 12 types of Grahas. Common symptoms include Jwara (Fever), Akasmika Rodana (Sudden crying spells), Akshi Vikunana (Twisting of eyes), Mushti Bandhana (Clenching of fists), Atisara/Chardi (Diarrhea/Vomiting), specific body odors

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Sarva Sharira, affecting mind and body

bheda: 12 types described, e.g., Skanda graha, Revati graha, Putana graha, etc., each with a unique clinical picture.

chikitsa.shamana:
This is treated with Daiva Vyapashraya and Yukti Vyapashraya chikitsa.
Daiva Vyapashraya: Mantra, Bali (offerings), Homa (rituals).
Yukti Vyapashraya: Internal medicines (Medhya, Deepaniya). Dhupana (medicated fumigation) and Abhyanga are very important.
chikitsa.shodhana: Gentle Shodhana like Mridu Virechana with milk and ghee can be performed. Parisheka (sprinkling medicated liquids) is also done.

purvarupa: A small, painless swelling (Granthi) that grows rapidly
rupa: Vritta/Ayata, Sthira, Manda Ruja, Mahamula, Ashu Vriddhi, Apaka Granthi (A rounded/elongated, fixed, slightly painful, deep-rooted, rapidly growing, non-suppurating mass)

samprapti.dosha: Tridoshaja (Vata causes division, Pitta causes rapid metabolism, Kapha causes growth)
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Can be localized or spread to other parts

bheda: Vataja, Pittaja, Kaphaja, Raktaja, Mamsaja, Medoja. Distinguished from Granthi by its rapid growth and non-suppurating nature.

chikitsa.shamana: This is primarily a surgical disease. Internal medicines are used to control growth and prevent recurrence. Lekhana (scraping) and Rasayana (rejuvenating) herbs are used.
chikitsa.shodhana: Shastra Karma (Wide Excision) is the primary treatment. This is followed by Kshara Karma (Chemical Cautery) or Agnikarma (Thermal Cautery) to destroy residual cells and prevent recurrence. Raktamokshana is also advised.

rupa: Danta Mamshebhyo Pooya-Rakta Srava (Discharge of pus and blood from the gums)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to the gums and tooth sockets

bheda: A severe Danta Mula Gata Roga (disease of the gums).

chikitsa.shamana: Local treatment is primary. Kavala/Gandusha with Tikta-Kashaya (bitter-astringent) decoctions. Pratisarana (rubbing gums) with specific powders.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (bloodletting from gums by leeches or scarification) is the main treatment to remove vitiated blood and pus. Nasya and Virechana are also performed.

correlation: Sinus Headache / Frontal Sinusitis (with solar pattern)
rupa: Surya Udaye Manda Vedana, Madhyahne Vriddhi, Aparaahne Kshaya (Pain starts mildly at sunrise, peaks at noon, and subsides in the evening)
Teevra Akshi-Bhru Shula (Severe pain in the eyes and eyebrows)
bheda: A specific type of Shiroroga (head disease).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Diet should be nourishing and primarily of sweet taste. Use milk, ghee, and rice.
Vihara: Avoid exposure to sun and heat.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehapana (internal oleation with medicated ghee) is a key treatment. Nasya Karma (nasal administration of medicine) is very effective. Mridu Virechana and Siravyadha are also performed.

rupa: Sarvada Nidra Pravritti (Constant urge to sleep, even during the day)
Not feeling refreshed even after long sleep

chikitsa.shamana:
Treatment is Kapha-Tamas hara (that which removes Kapha and Tamas).
Ahara: Laghu, Ruksha, Katu-Tikta-Kashaya diet. Use honey. Avoid sweets, dairy, and heavy foods.
Vihara: Avoid day sleep, engage in stimulating activities.
chikitsa.shodhana: Vamana (therapeutic emesis) is the best treatment. Tikshna Nasya (strong nasal drops) and Udvartana (dry powder massage) are also very effective. Langhana (fasting) is the first step.

rupa: Bheda-vat Shula (Splitting pain) specifically in the muscles (Mamsa)
bheda: A specific type of Gambhira Vatavyadhi (deep-seated Vata disorder).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Brimhana (nourishing) and Vatahara diet.
Vihara: Rest during acute pain. Gentle stretching.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana (internal/external) and Swedana (especially Pinda Sweda - bolus fomentation) are the mainstays of treatment. Virechana and Basti are used to pacify Vata systemically.

nidana: Stanya Dusti (Vitiated breast milk of the mother)
Kapha-Rakta Prakopaka Nidanas consumed by the mother
purvarupa: Mild redness of eyes in a newborn
rupa: Netra Kandu, Raga, Daha, Srava (Itching, redness, burning, and discharge from the eyes of a newborn)
Shishu Akshi Unmilane Ashaktaha (Infant is unable to open the eyes)

chikitsa.shamana:
Treatment of the mother and the child.
Mother: Given Tikta rasa pradhana diet and herbs to purify breast milk (Stanya Shodhana).
Child (Local): Aschyotana (eye drops) with breast milk or mild decoctions. Gentle Pratisarana (rubbing) on eyelids with Rasanjana.
chikitsa.shodhana: Mother should undergo Virechana. Siravyadha (venesection from forehead) of the child is mentioned but done with extreme care by experts.

rupa: Mukhe Niruja, Tanu, Shyama Mandala (Painless, thin, blackish patches on the face)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga (minor disease).

chikitsa.shamana:
Local application (Lepa) is the main treatment. Pastes of Manjistha, Chandana, Sariva, Arjuna twak are used.
Ahara: Pitta pacifying diet is essential.
chikitsa.shodhana: Siravyadha (venesection) and Jalauka (leech therapy) on the face are highly effective. Virechana is the best systemic treatment.

rupa: Guda Nirgamanam (Protrusion of the rectum outside the anus, especially during defecation)
It may be associated with Srava (discharge), Shula (pain), and Rakta Srava (bleeding)

chikitsa.shamana:
Local: Snehana (oleation of the prolapsed part with medicated oils) and Swedana (fomentation). This is followed by Sthapana (manual repositioning).
Procedure: Bandhana (specific bandaging technique) is advised.
chikitsa.shodhana: Basti (especially Anuvasana Basti) is very useful to strengthen the pelvic floor and pacify Vata. For severe cases, Agnikarma (cauterization) at 4 points around the anus or Shastra Karma (surgery) is performed.

rupa: Pidaka progresses to a painful, foul-smelling Vrana (ulcer) with profuse discharge
Associated with Jwara (fever) and Lasika Granthi Shotha (lymph node swelling)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to genitals but can affect the whole body if untreated

bheda: 5 types are described based on Dosha dominance.

chikitsa.shamana:
This is treated as a Dushta Vrana (infected ulcer).
Local: Frequent Parisheka (washing) with decoctions of Nimba, Triphala. Application of healing (Ropana) oils.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (leech therapy around the ulcer) is the primary treatment. Virechana (purgation) is performed to purify the system. If it does not heal, Agnikarma or Ksharakarma is done.

rupa: Danta Mamseshu Daha-Paka (Burning and suppuration/ulceration in the gums)
Mukhat Rakta-Pooya Srava (Discharge of blood and pus from the mouth)
bheda: A severe Danta Mula Gata Roga (disease of the gums).

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Kavala (gargling) with Tikta-Kashaya (bitter-astringent) decoctions. Pratisarana (rubbing) with honey and powders like Trikatu.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (bloodletting) by scarification (Prachchhanna) is the primary treatment. This is followed by Virechana to pacify systemic Pitta. Nasya is also advised.

purvarupa: Stiffness and weakness in one leg
rupa: Eka Sakthi Akarmanyata (Loss of function of one leg)
The patient walks with a limp (Khanjatvam)
Shosha (Atrophy of the leg muscles in chronic stage)
bheda: A type of Vatavyadhi. If both legs are affected, it is called Pangu (paraplegia).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Brimhana (nourishing) and Vatahara diet.
Vihara: Focus on rehabilitation and physiotherapy.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana (internal and external) and Swedana are key. Basti is the main line of treatment. Local procedures like Kati Basti and Pinda Sweda are also performed. Agnikarma is also indicated.

nidana: Guru-Snigdha-Sheeta Bhojana (Very heavy, oily, cold food)
purvarupa: Extreme lethargy and bloating after food
rupa: Doshas and Ama obstruct the food in Amashaya, preventing upward or downward movement (similar to Alasaka)
Extreme lethargy, sleepiness, and body stiffness
The patient is completely inactive and feels delayed (Vilamba) effects

samprapti.agni: Agni Nasha (Complete loss of digestive fire)
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Confined to Amashaya, affecting the whole body systemically

bheda: A severe, deadly complication of Ajeerna, part of the triad with Visuchika and Alasaka.

chikitsa.shamana: This is a medical emergency. Absolute fasting is critical. Swedana (fomentation) of the abdomen. No food or drink should be given.
chikitsa.shodhana: Inducing Vamana (emesis) with strong medicines is the only line of treatment to clear the obstruction. A Varti (suppository) is also used.

keyFormulations: Vamana Karaka Dravyas (Emetic herbs like Madanaphala)
Hingvashtak Churna (after the crisis is averted)

purvarupa: Pain and swelling of the foreskin
rupa: Charmasya Parivartanam (Foreskin retracts behind the glans penis and gets stuck)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga or Guhya Roga (disease of genital organs).

chikitsa.shamana:
This is an emergency requiring immediate intervention.
Local: Snehana (oleation with medicated ghee) and gentle Swedana (fomentation). This is followed by manual repositioning (Sthapana).
chikitsa.shodhana: If manual reduction fails, Shastra Karma (surgery - dorsal slit) is performed. Raktamokshana (leech therapy) can reduce swelling.

correlation: Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) with bleeding
nidana: Jala Pravesha (Water entry leading to severe infection)
rupa: Karnat Pooya-Rakta Srava (Discharge of pus mixed with blood from the ear)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to the ear canal and middle ear

bheda: A severe type of Karna Roga (ear disease).

chikitsa.shamana: Local treatment is primary. Karna Dhavana (cleaning the ear) with antimicrobial decoctions. Karna Dhupana (fumigation) with Guggulu. Karna Purana (instilling drops) with healing oils.
chikitsa.shodhana: Vamana, Virechana, and Nasya are performed to clear the Doshas from the head region. Raktamokshana from around the ear is also advised.

keyFormulations: Jatyadi Taila (for Karna Purana after cleaning)

rupa: Dirgha, Shotha-yukta, Stabdha Shundi (Elongated, swollen, and stiff uvula)
bheda: A type of Talu Roga (disease of the palate).

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Pratisarana (rubbing) with scraping (Lekhana) powders like Trikatu, Vacha, Saindhava. Kavala (gargling) is also advised.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (bloodletting by scarification or leeches on the uvula) is the primary treatment. Vamana, Dhumapana, and Nasya are also performed.

nidana: Abhighata (Trauma from weapons, falls, accidents etc.)
rupa: Chhinna (incised), Bhinna (punctured), Viddha (pierced), Kshata (lacerated), Pichchita (crushed), Ghrishta (abraded) - based on the type of wound
Twak-Mamsa Vidarana (Tearing of skin and muscle)

samprapti.dosha: Agantuja (Exogenous cause), later gets associated with Doshas
samprapti.dushya: Twak, Rakta, Mamsa and deeper tissues

bheda: Classified by the nature of the injury (Chhinna, Bhinna etc.).

chikitsa.shamana:
Immediate management is key.
1. Rakta Stambhana (Hemostasis) by Sandhana (pressure), Skandana (cold application), Dahana (cautery).
2. Vrana Shodhana (Wound cleaning).
3. Sandhana Karma (Suturing, if required).
4. Ropana (Application of healing medicines).
chikitsa.shodhana: This refers to the debridement and cleaning of the wound, not systemic Panchakarma.

correlation: Fever with symptoms of fat metabolism disorder
nidana: Untreated or improperly managed Jwara, where Doshas penetrate deeper
purvarupa: Symptoms of Rasa and Rakta Gata Jwara
rupa: Aruchi and Glani (Anorexia and profound fatigue)
bheda: A specific stage of Gambhira Jwara (deep-seated fever).

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment is Langhana (fasting) and Deepana-Pachana. Use bitter and pungent herbs to improve fat metabolism.
chikitsa.shodhana: Virechana (therapeutic purgation) is the main line of treatment. Niruha Basti (decoction enemas) with Lekhana (scraping) properties is also administered.

rupa: Masha-vat, Kathina, Sthira, Uchrita, Niruja, Krishna Granthi (A painless, hard, fixed, elevated, black-colored nodule on the skin, resembling a Masha/black gram)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga (minor disease). Different from Jatumani and Tilakalaka.

chikitsa.shamana: No effective medical management for removal.
chikitsa.shodhana: Treatment is para-surgical. Shastra (instrument) is used to hold and excise the lesion. This is followed by Kshara Karma (alkaline cautery) or Agnikarma (thermal cautery) on the base to prevent recurrence.

sadhyaAsadhyata: Asadhya (if patient is very weak), otherwise Krichra Sadhya
nidana: Complication of untreated or poorly managed Prameha (Diabetes Mellitus)
purvarupa: Appearance of a small, painless nodule
rupa: Maha Moola (Deep-rooted), Teevra Ruja (severe pain), Ashu Vriddhi (rapidly growing) abscesses
Occur in fleshy areas like Sphik (buttocks), Prishta (back), Amsa (shoulder)

samprapti.dushya: Meda, Mamsa, Rakta, Kleda (vitiated body fluids)
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Mamsa-Meda Bahula Sthana (Fleshy parts of the body)

bheda: 10 types are described, e.g., Sharavika, Kachchhapika, Jalini, etc., based on their appearance.

chikitsa.shamana: Strict management of Prameha (diabetes) is essential. Internal medicines focus on blood purification and improving metabolism.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is treated as a severe Vranashotha (abscess). Shastra Karma (Incision and Drainage) is the primary treatment. This is followed by meticulous Vrana Shodhana (wound cleaning) and Ropana (healing) procedures. Shodhana (Vamana/Virechana) for the systemic disease is also performed.

rupa: Antra Kujanam (Loud gurgling or rumbling sounds from the intestines)
Often associated with Adhmana (bloating) and Vayu Sancharana (movement of gas)
bheda: A primary symptom of Vata Prakopa in the GI tract.

chikitsa.shamana:
Treatment is Deepana-Pachana and Vatanulomana.
Ahara: Warm, light, and carminative diet. Use Hingu, Ajamoda, Shunthi, Jeeraka. Takra (buttermilk) is very beneficial.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehana and Swedana followed by Niruha Basti (decoction enema) with carminative herbs is the best treatment to regulate Vata.

reference: Charaka Samhita, Sutrasthana 20 (as a sign of Koshtha-gata Vata)

correlation: Tetanic Spasms (body stiff as a stick)
rupa: Sharira Danda-vat Stabdham (Entire body becomes rigid and stiff like a staff)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Sarva Sharira, affecting all muscles equally

bheda: A severe type of Vatavyadhi, related to Apatanaka but with a specific presentation of rigidity.

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment is palliative as the condition is considered Asadhya. The patient is kept in a dark, quiet room. Abhyanga (oil massage) and Nadi Sweda (steam fomentation) are performed to relieve spasms.
chikitsa.shodhana: Basti is the only feasible Shodhana, administered with great care to pacify Vata at its root.

nidana: Sevana of Dushta Jala (Drinking contaminated water containing the larvae)
rupa: Pada/Hasta Shotha (Swelling, usually on legs or arms)
Shotha bursts to form a Vrana (ulcer)
Sutropama Snayu Nirgamanam (A thread-like worm emerges from the ulcer)
Teevra Vedana, Daha, Jwara (Severe pain, burning, and fever)
upashaya: Sheeta Jala Parisheka (Pouring cold water, which encourages worm to emerge)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Twak and Mamsa of Shakha (Skin and muscles of limbs)

bheda: A specific type of Krimi Roga (parasitic disease).

chikitsa.shamana: Internal medicines are given to pacify inflammation and pain.
chikitsa.shodhana: The treatment is para-surgical. The emerging worm (Snayu) is carefully and slowly wound around a stick over several days without breaking it. Snehana and Swedana are performed. The wound is then treated as a Vrana.

nidana: Sheeta Vayu-Jala Samsparsha (Contact with cold wind/water)
rupa: Rakta Varna, Utsanna Mandala with Teevra Kandu (Red, elevated patches/wheals with intense itching)
Symptoms aggravate on exposure to cold
bheda: Closely related to Shitapitta, but considered Kapha-dominant and often chronic.

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Laghu, Ushna, Katu-Tikta diet. Avoid cold, heavy, sour foods, and dairy.
Local: Abhyanga with pungent oils (Sarshapa taila).
chikitsa.shodhana: Vamana (therapeutic emesis) is the best treatment to expel the vitiated Kapha. Virechana is also performed. Udvartana (dry powder massage) is beneficial.

purvarupa: Mild dryness and irritation in eyes
rupa: Gharsha, Parushya, Krichronmilana (Gritty sensation, roughness, and difficulty in opening/closing eyes)
bheda: A specific type of Sarvagata Netra Roga (disease affecting the whole eye).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Brimhana and Jeevaniya diet. Use milk, ghee, sweet fruits.
Local: Frequent application of lubricating drops (Aschyotana).
chikitsa.shodhana: Netra Tarpana (retaining medicated ghee over the eyes) is the primary treatment. Snehapana (internal oleation) with Triphala Ghrita followed by Mridu Virechana. Nasya is also very important.

keyFormulations: Triphala Ghrita (for Tarpana and internal use)

sadhyaAsadhyata: Sadhya to Asadhya (depending on depth and extent)
nidana: Agni Sparsha (Contact with fire, hot liquids, hot solids, radiation)
rupa: Durdagdha (2nd degree): Sphota (blisters), Teevra Daha, Raga.
Samyak Dagdha (3rd degree): Mamsa-avalambanam, destruction of tissues.
Ati Dagdha (4th degree): Sira-Snayu-Asthi Nasha (destruction of vessels, nerves, bones).

samprapti.dushya: Twak, Rakta, Mamsa and deeper tissues
samprapti.sancharaSthana: Localized to the burn area, but can cause systemic effects

bheda: Classified by depth (Plusta, Durdagdha etc.) and cause (fire, liquid etc.).

chikitsa.shamana: Immediate treatment is Sheeta Upachara (cooling therapies). Parisheka (pouring) with cold water or medicated decoctions. Lepa (application) of cooling and healing pastes (Ghrita, Chandana). Strict Pathya Ahara (diet) is followed.
chikitsa.shodhana: Refers to Vrana Shodhana (wound debridement) if infection occurs. Systemic Shodhana is contraindicated in the acute phase.

rupa: Sometimes associated with foul-smelling vaginal discharge
bheda: A specific type of Sutika Roga (puerperal disorder).

chikitsa.shamana: Treated on the lines of Ama Jwara. Langhana (fasting) is the first step. Deepana-Pachana herbs are given. Garbhashaya Shodhaka (uterine cleansing) herbs are used. Ahara should be very light.
chikitsa.shodhana: Not performed in the acute stage. After fever subsides, Mridu Virechana and Niruha Basti can be administered to cleanse the system.

correlation: Rickets / Infantile Malnutrition leading to delayed milestones
nidana: Guru-Madhura Ahara at an early age
rupa: Cheshta Hani (Inability to stand or walk even after one year of age)
Asthi Vakrata (Deformities of bones, like bow legs)

samprapti.sancharaSthana: Affects the entire body, especially the skeletal system

bheda: 3 types: Ksheeraja (due to milk issues), Garbhaja (due to maternal malnutrition), Vyadhija (due to other diseases).

chikitsa.shamana: Brimhana (nourishing) therapy is key. Abhyanga (massage) with medicated oils like Mahanarayana taila is very important. Ahara should be nourishing and include medicated ghee.
chikitsa.shodhana: Contraindicated due to the child's low strength.

rupa: Medhra Mani Avarana (Foreskin covers the glans penis and cannot be retracted)
Mutra Krichrata (Difficulty in urination, thin stream)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga or Guhya Roga (disease of genital organs). The opposite of Parivartika.

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Parisheka (pouring) with Vata-pacifying decoctions. Snehana (oleation) and gentle attempts at retraction. This is effective only in mild cases.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is primarily a surgical condition. Shastra Karma (Circumcision or a dorsal slit) is the definitive treatment.

keyFormulations: Surgical procedure is the main treatment

rupa: Mandala Utpatti (Appearance of rashes or circular patches)
bheda: A specific type of Gambhira Vatavyadhi (deep-seated Vata disorder).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Pitta-Vata pacifying diet. Use milk, ghee, Tikta dravyas.
Vihara: Avoid exposure to heat and sun.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (bloodletting) and Virechana (purgation) are the primary treatments. Basti is also administered after Shodhana.

rupa: Bhojane Krute Shulam (Severe pain that occurs *immediately* after eating)
bheda: A specific type of Shula (colic), distinguished from Parinama Shula by the timing of pain.

chikitsa.shamana: Ahara: Sheeta (cooling) and Madhura (sweet) diet. Milk, ghee, barley, and wheat are beneficial. Avoid spicy, sour, and hot foods.
chikitsa.shodhana: Vamana (therapeutic emesis) is the primary treatment to expel the aggravated Kapha and Pitta. After Vamana, Mridu Virechana (mild purgation) is performed.

nidana: Stanya Vega Dharana (Suppression of lactation urge)
rupa: Teevra Vedana, Raga, Shotha, Daha in Stana (Severe pain, redness, swelling, and burning in the breast)
anupashaya: Mardan (Pressure or massage in acute stage)

samprapti.dosha: Tridoshaja (Pitta is dominant, causing inflammation and suppuration)

bheda: A specific type of Vidradhi (abscess), located in the breast.

chikitsa.shamana:
Aama Avastha (Inflammatory stage): Lepa (poultice) to reduce inflammation and pain.
Pakva Avastha (Suppurated stage): Internal medicines have a supportive role.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is treated as a Shalya (surgical) condition. Once Pakva (ripened), the primary treatment is Patana Karma (Incision and Drainage), followed by Vrana Shodhana (wound cleaning) and Ropana (healing).

nidana: Vata aggravating factors (Ruksha, Sheeta, Laghu guna)
rupa: Twak Parushya/Sphutanam (Skin becomes rough and cracked)
bheda: A specific type of Gambhira Vatavyadhi (deep-seated Vata disorder).

chikitsa.shamana:
Ahara: Snigdha, Ushna, Madhura diet (oily, warm, sweet).
Vihara: Avoid exposure to cold and wind.
chikitsa.shodhana: Abhyanga (massage) and Swedana (fomentation) are the primary treatments. Snehapana (internal oleation) followed by Mridu Virechana and Basti are used to pacify Vata systemically.

rupa: Sukshma Srotas of Guda (Narrowing of the anal canal)
Krichhra Mala Pravritti (Straining and difficulty during defecation)

chikitsa.shamana: Local: Snehana (oleation) and Swedana (fomentation) of the anal region. Application of medicated oils.
chikitsa.shodhana: This is a para-surgical condition. The main treatment is mechanical dilation using a probe or finger (Varti/Anguli prayoga) after proper oleation. In severe cases, Shastra Karma (surgery) is performed.

nidana: Simultaneous aggravation of Doshas due to Viruddha Ahara, Ajeerna, Ritu Dosha, Sankramana (infection)

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment is challenging. First step is Langhana and Pachana to digest Ama. If Kapha is dominant, Atisara is controlled first. If Vata/Pitta are dominant, Jwara is controlled first. Use herbs that are both Jwaraghna (antipyretic) and Grahi (absorbent).
chikitsa.shodhana: Contraindicated in the acute stage.

bheda: A specific type of Gambhira Vatavyadhi (deep-seated Vata disorder).

chikitsa.shamana:
This is treated with Vajikarana (Aphrodisiac) and Vata-pacifying therapies.
Ahara: Use milk, ghee, Masha, Ashwagandha, Kapikacchu.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehapana followed by Mridu Virechana. Basti is the most important treatment, especially Yapana Basti (rejuvenating enemas) and Uttara Basti.

rupa: Danta Chalanam (Mobility of one or more teeth)
Shotha in Dantamula (Swelling of the gums)
bheda: A specific Danta Mula Gata Roga (disease of the gums).

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment aims to firm up the gums and pacify Vata. Kavala/Gandusha with Kashaya (astringent) decoctions or oils. Pratisarana (rubbing gums) with powders that strengthen gums.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (bloodletting) to relieve inflammation. Nasya with nourishing oils is very useful. Basti is used for systemic Vata control.

correlation: Nasal Vestibulitis / Furuncle in the Nose
nidana: Nasa Kanduyana (Picking or scratching the nose)
purvarupa: Itching and pain inside the nostril
rupa: Nasa Antah Shotha-Raga-Ruja (Swelling, redness, and severe pain inside the nostril)
The tip of the nose swells and resembles a vulture's beak (Gridhra Nasa)

chikitsa.shamana:
Treated on the lines of Pittaja Vranashotha (inflammatory abscess).
Local: Gentle Nasya with ghee. Lepa with cooling herbs like Chandana. Avoid squeezing.
chikitsa.shodhana: Raktamokshana (leech therapy near the lesion) is the primary treatment. Virechana is the best systemic Shodhana.

keyFormulations: Jatyadi Ghrita (for local application after rupture)

rupa: Snigdha, Savarna, Grathita, Niruja Pidaka (Smooth, skin-colored, knotted, painless eruptions)
Resembles the shape of Aja-gala (goat's udder)
bheda: A type of Kshudra Roga (minor disease).

chikitsa.shamana: Medical management is generally not effective for removal.
chikitsa.shodhana: Treatment is para-surgical. Shastra Karma (excision or scraping of the lesion) is the definitive treatment. This is followed by Kshara Karma or Agnikarma to prevent recurrence.

correlation: Infantile disease from mother's subsequent pregnancy
nidana: Mother conceiving again while still breastfeeding the previous child
anupashaya: Continuing breastfeeding from the pregnant mother

samprapti.dushya: Stanya (Breast milk), which becomes vitiated due to the new pregnancy

bheda: A specific Bala Roga (pediatric disease) with a unique cause.

chikitsa.shamana: The first and most important step is to wean the child from the mother's milk. The child is then treated on the lines of Bala Shosha (marasmus) or Grahani (malabsorption) with Deepana, Pachana, and Brimhana therapies.
chikitsa.shodhana: Contraindicated in infants.

rupa: Muhurmuhuh Anga Vikshepanam (Repeated, forceful, involuntary jerking movements of the limbs)
Patient is usually conscious during the episode
Different from Apasmara, where there is loss of consciousness and frothing
bheda: A Vataja Nanatmaja Vyadhi (caused solely by Vata).

chikitsa.shamana: Treatment is pure Vata pacification. Patient is kept in a quiet environment. Abhyanga with warm, Vata-pacifying oils.
chikitsa.shodhana: Snehapana followed by Mridu Virechana. Basti is the main line of treatment. Nasya and Shirodhara are also crucial.
